terrain: low and nearly level sandy coral islands with narrow fringing reefs that have developed at the top of submerged volcanic mountains which in most cases rise steeply from the ocean floor
geography - note: scattered vegetation consisting of grasses prostrate vines and low growing shrubs; primarily a nesting roosting and foraging habitat for seabirds shorebirds and marine wildlife; closed to the public

Johnston Island and Sand Island are natural islands which have been expanded by coral dredging; North Island (Akau) and East Island (Hikina) are manmade islands formed from coral dredging; the egg-shaped reef is 34 km in circumference; closed to the public
barren coral atoll with deep interior lagoon; closed to the public
a coral atoll managed as a NWR and open to the public for wildlife-related recreation in the form of wildlife observation and photography
the high rainfall and resulting lush vegetation make the environment of this atoll unique among the US Pacific Island territories; supports a large undisturbed stand of Pisonia beach forest
legal system: the laws of the US where applicable apply

location: atoll in the North Pacific Ocean 1830 nm (3389 km) southwest of Honolulu about half way between Hawaii and Australia
island in the North Pacific Ocean 1815 nm (3361 km) southwest of Honolulu about half way between Hawaii and Australia
island in the South Pacific Ocean 1305 nm (2417 km) south of Honolulu about half way between Hawaii and Cook Islands
atoll in the North Pacific Ocean 717 nm (1328 km) southwest of Honolulu about one-third of the way from Hawaii to the Marshall Islands
reef in the North Pacific Ocean 930 nm (1722 km) south of Honolulu about half way between Hawaii and American Samoa
atoll in the North Pacific Ocean 1260 nm (2334 km) northwest of Honolulu near the end of the Hawaiian Archipelago about one-third of the way from Honolulu to Tokyo
atoll in the North Pacific Ocean 960 nm (1778 km) south of Honolulu about half way between Hawaii and American Samoa
natural hazards: the narrow fringing reef surrounding the island poses a maritime hazard
wet or awash most of the time maximum elevation of less than 2 m makes Kingman Reef a maritime hazard
dependency status: unincorporated territories of the US; administered from Washington DC by the Fish and Wildlife Service of the US Department of the Interior as part of the National Wildlife Refuge system

incorporated Territory of the US; partly privately owned and partly federally owned; administered from Washington DC by the Fish and Wildlife Service of the US Department of the Interior; the Office of Insular Affairs of the US Department of the Interior continues to administer nine excluded areas comprising certain tidal and submerged lands within the 12 nm territorial sea or within the lagoon
flag description: the flag of the US is used
area - comparative: about two and a half times the size of The Mall in Washington DC
about three times the size of The Mall in Washington DC
about eight times the size of The Mall in Washington DC
about four and a half times the size of The Mall in Washington DC
a little more than one and a half times the size of The Mall in Washington DC
about nine times the size of The Mall in Washington DC
about 20 times the size of The Mall in Washington DC
population: public entry is only by special-use permit from US Fish and Wildlife Service and generally restricted to scientists and educators; visited annually by US Fish and Wildlife Service
in previous years an average of 1100 US military and civilian contractor personnel were present; as of May 2005 all US government personnel had left the island
approximately 40 people make up the staff of US Fish and Wildlife Service and their services contractor living at the atoll
four to 20 Nature Conservancy US Fish and Wildlife staff and researchers
climate: equatorial; scant rainfall constant wind burning sun
tropical but generally dry; consistent northeast trade winds with little seasonal temperature variation

subtropical with cool moist winters (December to February) and warm dry summers (May to October); moderated by prevailing easterly winds; most of the 1067 mm (42 in) of annual rainfall occurs during the winter

equatorial hot; located within the low pressure area of the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) where the northeast and southeast trade winds meet it is extremely wet with between 4000-5000 mm (160-200 in) of rainfall each year
airports: one abandoned World War II runway of 1665 m covered with vegetation and unusable

airstrip constructed in 1937 for scheduled refueling stop on the round-the-world flight of Amelia EARHART and Fred NOONAN; the aviators left Lae New Guinea for Howland Island but were never seen again; the airstrip is no longer serviceable
lagoon was used as a halfway station between Hawaii and American Samoa by Pan American Airways for flying boats in 1937 and 1938
3 - one operational (2377 m paved); no fuel for sale except emergencies
elevation extremes: Baker Island unnamed location - 8 m; Howland Island unnamed location - 3 m; Jarvis Island unnamed location - 7 m; Johnston Atoll Sand Island - 10 m; Kingman Reef unnamed location - less than 2 m; Midway Islands unnamed location - 13 m; Palmyra Atoll unnamed location - 3 m
